header: I am happy to welcome the new subscribers. There are now 1020 members! Most of them came in response to friends sending out invitations to their respective Perl Monger lists.
If you find the Perl Weekly usefule and you think others could also benefit from it, invite them. Send a copy of the Perl Weekly with your recommendation. That works wonders.

entries.title: Perl polls launched with the first poll on where you get Perl news and what articles would you like to read.
Perl 5.15.3 released
entries.text: Ahmad M. Zawawi (azawawi) reports that a new development version of perl was released and shows how to install it.

entries.title: Abstracting the company away (part 2)
entries.text: In this part SaweyerX explains how in their company called Kitties Inc. they abstract away all the database access and authentication issues in a separater role.

entries.title: Perl and Parsing 9: 'Use' and the Ruby Slippers
entries.text: Jeffrey Kegler, in his Ocean of Awareness explains the 'use' statement of Perl. Probably way more than you'd every want to know about it. Unless of course, you would like to understand how it works. It's not easy so Jeffrey get some help from the Wizard of Oz.

entries.title: Enchant closures for better debugging output
entries.text: On th Effective Perl Programming site brian d foy developes the MagicalCodeRef module to allow you to see, well, more or less, what is in a code-ref without execution the code.

entries.title: Automating Telephony with Perl and Twilio
entries.text: Scott Wiersdorf explains how Twillo works and how the Perl API of Twillo can be used to make synthesized phone calls. From Perl.

entries.title: Perl 5.16 and Beyond
entries.text: Jesse Vincent, the pumking of Perl posted his vision how perl 5 will evolve in the coming years. This is a textual version of his presentation at YAPC. Originally posted to the Perl 5 porters mailing list and here reposted and discussed on LWN.

entries.title: Using strict is hard, let's just use Moose;
entries.text: Fred Moyer (Phred) wonders how come Moose users don't use strict. somethingdoug comes to the rescue and explains it very nicely but eventually points out the educational problem in the lack of use strict statements in Moose using code.

entries.title: I <3/> XML::Rabbit
entries.text: This is a short entry by Mark Gardner but imporant as it shows how a little (positive!) feedback to a CPAN author goes a long way to get thing rolling further. Robin Smidsr√∏d, the author of XML::Rabbit commented on the blog and made some improvements to the module. Now we only need to understand what is XML::Rabbit?

entries.title: Introducing Plack::Test::Agent
entries.text: This is actually the third article in a short few days in which chromatic is exploring how to test a Plack application. This is all part of the big plan to write the little Plack book. You'll find the other articles linked from this one.

entries.title: Simple::Redis Perl 6 module
entries.text: Woodi (slunski) started to build a Perl 6 interface to Redis, the key-value store.
